question: Ada, how are you settling in? Are you liking the farm?
answer: Very much. It's beautiful country.

question: So listen -- if you would say hello to one of these fools, I'll get a field cleared this weekend.
answer: Anyone? Like a forfeit?

question: Hello. I'm Ada Monroe.
answer: I'm Inman.

question: Inman?
answer: W. P. Inman.

question: W. P. Inman.
answer: Repeating a thing doesn't improve it. People call me Inman.

question: If you were to take a glass of lemonade your friends might stop staring. Inman.
answer: They're not my friends. Thank you.

question: And what do you do?
answer: I work wood. Got a piece of land. Mostly work wood.

question: Clear fields?
answer: I can clear a field.

question: So, was there something in particular you wished to say to me?
answer: Not that comes to me. I'll say thank you for the lemonade.

question: That's a fine looking thing.
answer: I've been missing it.

question: Thank you, by the way. Inman's down in the bottom field, clearing his debt.
answer: Oh dear. And then he had nothing to say.

question: He was happy.
answer: Really?

question: Are men so different in Charleston?
answer: Men? I don't know. I don't even know what a woman should be like. In Charleston I was called a thistle, twice, by two different men. Both of them -- they were hunting for a simile, what was I like -- and thistle came right to them.

question: Were you planning to come inside?
answer: I'm wetter than a fish.

question: There's a good fire going.
answer: I'm all right.

question: Somebody said you were enlisting. Are you?
answer: If there's a war we'll all fight.

question: If there's a mountain we'll all climb, if there's an ocean we'll all drown.
answer: Call a thing a war makes it a challenge to some men.

question: Did you get a picture made?
answer: Say again.

question: A tintype, with your gun and your courage on display.
answer: You're laughing at me.

question: I don't know you.
answer: You're always carrying a tray.

question: I'm taking a drink over to the negroes in the barn.
answer: I'll do that. I can't get much wetter.

question: I'll do that. I can't get much wetter.
answer: Mr. Inman.

question: Reverend.
answer: What can I do for you?

question: I have some sheet music. Belonged to my father. No use to me.
answer: You must come in.

question: The only slaves within twenty miles labor on my farm. They're good Christians and I'll vouchsafe for them.
answer: What?

question: You're looking -- at this moment, I don't know why -- you're looking exactly like your mother.
answer: Every time you see the doctor you get melancholy.

question: He listens to my heart and I get emotional.
answer: He gives you alcohol and you get emotional.

question: We commiserate about the folly of this terrible war. Do you worry when there's no word from him? From Mr. Inman?
answer: Yes. But then I've tried counting the number of words which passed between Mr. Inman and me. Is that a bonfire? So close to the barns. What's going on?

question: Hey! Stop there! Hey! Dear God.
answer: No, Daddy, it's not real.

question: What is wrong with us all?
answer: I'll get help. Keep away from the flames.

question: Thank you. For your Providence, Oh lord, we thank you.
answer: Amen. That was the last of the ham.

question: It was delicious.
answer: I have to learn how to cook.

question: I was going to say something in Chapel. Perhaps some of the womenfolk will volunteer.
answer: I can't have people coming here and cooking for me!

question: It's my fault. I should have raised you less like a companion and more like a young woman. I'm sorry.
answer: I'm not sorry, but I don't know how we'll get through another winter.

question: Will you play me something? Something peaceful while I look over my sermon.
answer: Daddy, bring the tablecloth in with you! Daddy, come inside before you drown! Dear Mr. Inman...

question: Daddy, bring the tablecloth in with you! Daddy, come inside before you drown! Dear Mr. Inman...
answer: It's come to you by way of Virginia. It's not too recent -- written this past winter. I'm afraid I can't read who it's from. Dear Mr. Inman,

question: -- I'm still waiting, as I promised I would, but I find myself alone and at the end of my wits --
answer: -- at the end of my wits, so now I say to you, plain as I can, come back to me. Come back to me is my request. Then something I can't read, something, come back to me.

question: Is there a letter for me? I know. Thank you so much. What do you hear?
answer: It's taken me too long, but I've come to pay my respects.

question: Thank you.
answer: I reckoned you might need fattening up. This house must bring bad luck. Killed my granddaddy to lose it, then my daddy died on account of not having it, then your daddy died on account of getting it. We should burn it down.

question: Didn't somebody try?
answer: Lot to manage without help. Need a hand with that pump?

question: No.
answer: I'm happy to volunteer.

question: But not to volunteer for the war?
answer: The war? I wanted to go. But you know

question: You've got no spleen.
answer: That's the thing about an organ. You don't know you need it till you lost it. I want to clear this path. I can just as soon do it and talk as stand around and talk. Then you can say men beat a path to your door.

question: I'd really prefer it if you didn't do that.
answer: Would you rather I did my job? See if there's any material I should confiscate. For the war effort.

question: I was raised in the good manners of the South where a gentleman doesn't enter a house with a woman alone.
answer: Good manners didn't quite make it to these mountains. If it don't yield meat, or you can't sit on it, or suck on it... And you're sleeping all right? These cold dark nights?

question: I'm sleeping fine.
answer: It's going to be a long hard winter.

question: Getting better all the time.
answer: Seems that way.

question: I wouldn't hurry. War's almost done.
answer: Where'd you take your wound?

question: Before I was born. Never saw a thing in this world, not a tree a gun or a woman. Though I put my hand on all three. Couple of things I felt back there I'd sure liked to have had a long look at.
answer: What would you give for that? To have your eyeballs back for ten minutes?

question: Ten minutes! Wouldn't give an Indian head cent. I fear it might turn me hateful.
answer: That's sure what seeing's done to me.

question: That ain't the way I meant it. You said ten minutes. It's having a thing and then the loss I'm talking about.
answer: Then we don't agree. There's not much I wouldn't give for ten minutes of someplace.

question: Someplace or someone.
answer: Same difference.

question: That your daddy's coat?
answer: I was saying to Sally, I wasn't expecting to be visiting, so...

question: Don't suit you. I can't get up to your place this week. She's mad at me --
answer: I don't expect -

question: Yesterday I found myself crouched over a well like a mad woman, which I suppose I have become -- and staring down into its secrets, I thought I saw you there, walking back to me -- -- or wished I did.
answer: That cow wants milking. If that letter ain't urgent, the cow is -- is what I'm saying.

question: I don't know you.
answer: Old Lady Swanger says you need some help. Here I am.

question: I need help, I need, I do need help, but I need a laborer -- there's plowing and rough work and -- I think there's been a misunderstanding.
answer: What's the rake for?

question: The rake?
answer: Ain't for gardening, that's for sure. Number one -- you got a horse I can plow all day. I'm a worker. Number two there's no man better than me cause there's no man around who ain't old or full of mischief. I know your plight.

question: My plight?
answer: Am I hard to hear cause you keep repeating everything. I'm not looking for money, never cared for it and now it ain't worth nothing. I expect to board and eat at the same table. I'm not a servant. Do you get my meaning?

question: You're not a servant.
answer: People'll have to empty their own night jars, that's my point.

question: Right.
answer: And I'm not planning to work while you watch neither.

question: Right.
answer: Is that a yes or a no?

question: Yes.
answer: There's half the day yet. Let's make a start. My name's Ruby. I know your name.

question: The rake
answer: I despise a flogging rooster. Where is he? Let's put him in a pot.

question: Ada? Ada? You up?
answer: Yes. It's still dark.

question: Tell the cows that. It's late.
answer: I have to eat something.

question: Then you have to get up earlier. What's that?
answer: A novel.

question: You want to carry a book carry one you can write in -- -- we got our own story. Called Black Cove Farm I can spell it, too. C-a-t-a-s-t-r-o- phe. Learned the same place you did, in the schoolroom. That's one of the first words they taught me. Ruby Thewes, you are a ca-t-a-s-t-r-o-p-h- e... You mucking out? Three years I was in school before my daddy -- saying God rest his soul is like wishing him what he had in life, cause he lived to rest, he was born tired -- before my daddy decided there was better use for my backside than have it sat all day in front of a blackboard. Number One -- layout a winter garden for cool season crops Number Two
answer: Maul?

question: M-a-u-l.
answer: I have no idea.

question: Number three Clear and turn this field. No harm done letting it go fallow, now we'll do well. Number fifteen
answer: Sixteen.

question: Number sixteen
answer: What's a Gourd House?

question: There's survival. On them trees. You got a cider press or would that be wishing on a blessing?
answer: Actually, yes, I think we do.

question: Don't let go. Just back up, nice and steady, do this all in reverse, you're going to end up with her draped back over your animal.
answer: Don't pull that trigger. I am a man of God.

question: I've killed several of them.
answer: I mean I am God's minister.

question: What part of God's business is throwing a woman down a gorge.
answer: A slave woman, can you see that in this light? She's black as a bucket of tar.

question: Is she dead?
answer: Drugged her. Like you would a butterfly. And I care for her, that's the heartbreak of it. She's got my bastard in her belly. What kind of pistol is that I never saw the like of it? I'm begging you. It's better you blowout my brains than return me to this place.

question: Where does she live?
answer: In our house. She sleeps in our kitchen. You don't know me, friend, but the good Lord punished me with want. I am all appetite. That's all I do all day is want

question: Shut your mouth. I don't want a sermon every time I ask a question. This your place?
answer: Dear God of misery.

question: You're going to put her back where she sleeps.
answer: I do that the Members will lynch me. Consorting with a nigger, adultery, siring a bastard while serving as their preacher. We're a strict congregation we've churched men for picking up a fiddle on the sabbath.

question: So you reckoned to kill her.
answer: There's a back door. Have pity. Thank you. I was going to do a grievous wrong.

question: You find me some paper and a pen.
answer: You're not entitled to judge me! You're nothing but an outlier, plain as daylight!

question: Morning. Pigs
answer: No. What? No. We bought our hams.

question: There's a world more to a hog than the two hams! Lard, for example, we'll need plenty -- The catastrophe of Ada Monroe's laundry. I can feel you shutting your eyes. What's this wood?
answer: I don't know. Locust?

question: Where's North?
answer: North is, North is --

question: Name me three herbs growing wild on this farm.
answer: I can't! I can't! All right? I can talk about farming in Latin. Will that do? I can read French. I know Harmony and Counterpoint. I know my Bible. I can name the principal rivers of Europe, but don't ask me to name one stream in this county. I can embroider, but I can't darn, I can arrange cut flowers, but I can't grow them. If a thing has a function, if I might do something with it, it wasn't considered suitable.

question: Why?
answer: Ruby, you could ask why? about pretty much everything to do with me. This fence is about the first thing I've ever done that'll produce an actual result.

question: For five dollars I wouldn't give a parched man a dipper of this riverwater.
answer: Sign says ferry, five dollars.

question: This look like a ferry? My Daddy's dead, or gone off to the Federals, don't matter which. I'm the way across now.
answer: What's the name of this thing?

question: Nothing but the mighty Cape Fear River, is all. Nobody crosses this water unless they're running from someplace. Some cross one way, some the other
answer: I can give you thirty dollars script.

question: Keep going. We're both in trouble.
answer: No. Get out.

question: It's Homeguard. Made me tell them all about you.
answer: I should have shot you when I had the chance.

question: I'm not looking for revenge, by the way. For what you did to me. No, I'm a Pilgrim now, like you, traveling the road, paying our dues, relying on the kindness of strangers.
answer: You're nothing like me and the last thing I want right now is a conversation.

question: You recall Job in the scriptures? I will give free utterance to my complaint. I will speak in the bitterness of my soul. That's our friend here... They cut off my hair. Which was hard. I was vain about my hair. I had good curls. But I deserved it. I'm the Reverend Veasey. Have I seen you in church?
answer: I'm saving for a cowhide, and when I get it I aim to get a saddle made, and when I get me a saddle I'll save for a horse, and when I got a horse I'll throw on the saddle, and then you won't see my sorry ass round this swamp again.

question: What's that?
answer: Catfish. 'gator. Keep your hand in the boat. Already looks like some critter chewed his neck. Thirty more dollars, we can go to the cabin. I'll pull this dress over my head.

question: Agricola poetis viam non monstrat.
answer: Which means?

question: The farmer does not point out the road to a poet.
answer: Which means? Should be the other way round

question: Which means, I suppose, which means the poet should know where he's going.
answer: It's no wonder you're helpless and hopeless if it takes this long to fix your hair. Say some more.

question: Terra mutata non mutat mores. It's appalling what's in my head.
answer: It's appalling what's in my head?

question: No, it means
answer: Well that's surely true even in English.

question: You can keep those earrings.
answer: We can't keep anything.

question: I have to keep the bangles. They were my mother's.
answer: Well that's all. The rest is for trading. Else they can bury you in your finery.

question: You're done.
answer: Good God! Okay.

question: I like it.
answer: Takes two minutes. That's what I like. How much do you love that piano? We're careful we'll get through the winter now. I made old man Roy give me ten of those sheep on account of I said they were so small put together they were no bigger than six proper sheep.

question: My father always wanted sheep on this land.
answer: I'm sorry you had to lose your piano. I cut off my hair once, for money. My daddy got two dollars for it. Made a wig for a rich feller in Raleigh. Stobrod called himself a musician -- my daddy -- he could play six tune on a fiddle. Got himself shot dead at Petersburg. I was like his goat or some creature tethered to a post. He left me once, up the mountains. I was eight. He was gone over two weeks.

question: Oh Ruby.
answer: I was all right! He'd walk forty miles for liquor and not forty inches for kindness.

question: And your mother?
answer: Never met her. We're the same in that regard. He said she was -- he told me a thousand stories -- she was a wolf or an indian or a donkey. Don't say much for him, except you know he'd be fast to work up a sweat on a tree if he thought there was pleasure in it. There's cows to milk.

question: You'll find the good Lord very flexible on the subject of property. We could do a lot with this saw... Why you in such a hurry the whole time? Hurry or slow the destination is always the same. It's only the journey that is different. That's either in the Good Book or I made it up. Good day to you!
answer: My old bull, wandered off and died in this here creek. Fouled up our water is how I found it.

question: This is a tricky one. The name for the Bull's member is a tassel. I learned that and never forgot it.
answer: Reckon I need a train of mules.

question: There'll be a tang, I'd imagine. There's my place. Hope you can stomach a yard chock-full of females. Brought my woman home, she showed up with her three so-called sisters and their brats. The noise in that place is something awful. It's why I go hunting.
answer: Looks a bit crooked.

question: It is on a bit of a tilt. Them females. They all roll down one end each night!
answer: -- Roll me over!

question: -- In the clover
answer: One good fart -- that'll tip over! Oh God of my God! Hallelujah! Hallelujah!

question: What's up?
answer: The Israelites! The tribes of Israel are about to flee from the banks of Egypt! Hallelujah!

question: Good God. These two boys is stopping for supper. They're on the road to Atonement.
answer: Atonement is not a place.

question: So what is it when it's at home?
answer: Those are fine examples of the female.

question: Take them all and leave the saw. Be a sight more use. They love to scrub a man. Put the water on the boil. It's my liquor, gets their titties swinging.
answer: God damn! I was right about sheep droppings those stools -- like rock hard. Quite astonishing. He's a hero. Took that wound at Petersburg.

question: Dolly? Dolly, Lila, Shyla and Mae. That's a poem. That's a poem. Dolly, Lila, Shyla and Mae Da-da da-da da-da dae... ...there's a poem there.
answer: I'm leaving soon as I'm full.

question: Really. Goodbye.
answer: Got a bunch of traps needs visiting. I'll be back tomorrow, before dark. You'll still be here?

question: That's my fervent prayer.
answer: My house is your house.

question: Like to wash their hands and pray.
answer: Say again?

question: Dolly, Lila, Shyla and Mae.
answer: That's Job. Don't say much but even liquored up there's a preacher in him.

question: I'll say my goodbyes, got miles and miles to go before sunset. I'll just quickly lie down.
answer: I'm heading for that smokehouse and I'm ready to be washed clean of my dirt.

question: We need a scarecrow, birds eating up half our winter garden.
answer: Sally's right. We should both stop toiling and stand a while with our arms stretch out. I'll volunteer.

question: We got something for you.
answer: For all your kindness. Coffee. And a pie.

question: That strike you as odd?
answer: What?

question: Stood at her front door?
answer: Sally?

question: Number one -- I know that woman all my life. I never stood outside her house -- she'd invite a wolf inside if it knocked on the door.
answer: Perhaps, I don't know, perhaps she was busy.

question: Number two -- Old Man Swanger was inside that house
answer: What about them?

question: He's dead. This man's dead!
answer: Am I so altered that they don't see me? I christened that child.

question: You run, we're all running with you, the lame and the stupid, of which we number both. Just give me some warning so I can tell the guard -- I'm not getting shot again for some cause I don't believe in.
answer: That's Rebecca. That's Rebecca. Rebecca! Is it well with you? I've been repenting for what I did. I've walked the road of atonement. God Bless you. I'm with you. I got a baby coming.

question: It's a coon or possum. Scratched out a fist hole in the side. This place! I'm telling you -- we grow, others eat. I'll go into town, take the last of the cider and trade for a trap.
answer: What you looking to catch?

question: What?
answer: With that trap.

question: We got some critter stealing our corn.
answer: Still but the two of you up there, is it?

question: You know it.
answer: When we get a cold night, camped out, trying to keep the rule of law, protecting girls like you from Federals and deserters, that's a thought warms us ain't it? -- the two of you up there on my Grand-daddy's farm, dressed in men's clothes. Warms us right up. What you got in the sacks? Looks like human heads! Eh? Looks like a bunch of heads. We got competition!

question: Mind that Billy, he's the jealous kind. Pay no attention to me. What happened to your head?
answer: Fighting.

question: And your neck?
answer: Different fighting.

question: You're the color of a cadaver. I'll fix you. I can fix you up.
answer: Mister -- you could fix me I'd be in your everlasting debt.

question: The hat's a nice touch. You're quiet.
answer: I cried for my Daddy. I dressed up the scarecrow in his suit and he came back, his arms out, said you never cried enough, you never cried enough.

question: Well now you did.
answer: Then I thought, it's not my Daddy, it's my sweetheart. I saw him once that way, when I looked down Sally's well. So I dressed the scarecrow in the dress I wore the day he left. In case his spirit flies over looking out for me. That looks terrible. Cabbages.

question: I bargained like Lucifer. We can make all kinds of good eating.
answer: Such as?

question: Afternoon.
answer: Don't spread out. Why they spreading out?

question: I'm not spreading out. I'm sitting here. Never knew a man worked in his field with a shotgun.
answer: There's a war on.

question: Get off my land.
answer: Your boys come back.

question: Ain't seen my boys in four years. They're fighting other boys, not old men and women.
answer: He means us. He's referring there to us. So you won't care if we take a look around?

question: What I gotta give you? A chicken? A lamb?
answer: Sure.

question: Right then.
answer: Thing is -- you got one barrel and there's five of us. Not a fair fight.

question: I can't get this damn thing off her.
answer: Dear Lord in heaven.

question: Ada, I can't get this off her! What darling? What? She's saying don't bother.
answer: Wait! There's someone down there. I think it's Esco.

question: How long have I been sleeping?
answer: Not long enough.

question: I can't stop here. I'm a deserter. They find me here things could be bad for you.
answer: What they going to do? Cut short my young life? Sit down before you fall down.

question: How long you been up here?
answer: What year are we? '63?

question: Last time I checked it was '64.
answer: I'd say twenty six years.

question: Twenty six years!
answer: I could move on anytime. I've seen most of the world anyway, Richmond in the North, south almost to Charleston. You're going somewhere or you are somewhere, what's the difference? I've learned a person can survive off pretty much of a goat. I can't abide a chicken, but a goat gives you company and milk and cheese and then, when you need it, good meat. So you've been fighting?

question: I could be at killing for days sometimes, in the hand to hand, my feet against the feet of my enemy and I always killed him and he never killed me.
answer: He gave it a try, to look at you.

question: I guess he did.
answer: See I think there's a plan. There's a design. For each and every one of us. You look at nature, a bird flies somewhere, picks up a seed, shits the seed out, a plant grows. Bird's got a job, seed's got a job. Take one of these now with your food. Swallow it. If you die I'll give you your money back. Our minds aren't made to hold on to the particulars of pain, the way we do bliss.

question: It's true...
answer: What is?

question: What you remember.
answer: What's her name?

question: Ada. -- Sometimes I think I'm crazy when I'm just hungry -- Ada Monroe.
answer: And is she waiting for you?

question: She was. I don't know. Or if she'd know me. I'm like the boy who goes out in winter for firewood comes back in the spring with a whistle.
answer: Now drink this. It visits the pain. And you'll sleep.

question: I've had to put myself in the way of people's kindness.
answer: I hope you found it.

question: The passenger pigeons fly south, the berries ripen. Whether I see them or not, whether a man dies, or a war is won.
answer: That's the laudanum getting to you. That's good. Say something more. Raise that up for me.

question: It's a man.
answer: What is?

question: Raiding our corn. Got him in the trap. That's him yelping.
answer: You're not going to shoot him!

question: I don't want him to shoot me. Can you fire this thing?
answer: Yes.

question: Listen up -- you got a barrel trained on your rear-end.
answer: Get me out of this dang thing. My fist's about to drop off.

question: You got a weapon?
answer: No ma'am. I'm begging you. I'm already on my knees, otherwise I'd get down on them.

question: Unbelievable! Stobrod Thewes.
answer: Ruby? God damn!

question: That's my daddy...
answer: Just so's you know -- I can eat while she's doing this -- in case you're holding off.

question: Just so's you know -- you're not eating inside. Number One -- they hang people round here for taking in deserters. Number two -- even if they gave out prizes -- you'd still eat outside.
answer: You're scarred.

question: I'm what?
answer: Your heart. Scarred. I did wrong to you.

question: You'd be scarred. You'd be really scarred if I hadn't wrapped them trap teeth in sacking. Which was her idea.
answer: I hurt you.

question: Good God!
answer: I wrote fifty tunes with you in mind. Ruby this, Ruby that, Ruby with the eyes that sparkle.

question: Hey! Let's agree
answer: I'm changed. People change. War changes people something terrible. Ruby's told you -- I've no doubt -- I wasn't always the best...

question: You were an asshole.
answer: I can't disagree with that. I was.

question: Get him out of here!
answer: Music's changed me. I'm full of music, darling. I wish I'd brung my fiddle Hey Ruby! Got a new fiddle -- it's got a little snake's rattle in the body -- took it off a dead federal in Virginia. That's a beautiful fiddle. It's full of tunes, Ruby. Don't know if it's from that little rattle locked up in it, or from something untied my heart.

question: You're all set.
answer: Bless you both.

question: Ain't you got a proper coat?
answer: Darling, I'm fine. And you just say the word, I won't come back neither. I don't want to put either you or your mistress here in any bother.

question: Get on back where you came from!
answer: My love for Heathcliff resembles the eternal rocks beneath -- a source of little visible delight, But necessary.

question: She ain't gonna marry Linton, is she? She said -- whatever our souls are made of his and mine are the same. You can't say that and then marry Linton.
answer: We'll find out.

question: Okay.
answer: Tomorrow.

question: I'm not waiting until tomorrow.
answer: Ruby, I'm falling asleep.

question: I'm one man alone. I'm a Confederate soldier on furlough. I have no bad intention. I need shelter and food. Can I at least sleep in the corn crib -- just for some shelter? I'll be on my way come morning.
answer: I've got a rifle.

question: Fair enough.
answer: There's some beans and corn pone, all I got. You better come in.

question: Thank you.
answer: I'm alone here, as you can see, with my baby. I need to believe you mean no harm.

question: No, I mean to give it to you.
answer: I don't want it. I had my way they'd take metal altogether out of this world. Every blade, every gun.

question: Is your baby sick?
answer: He cries. I don't know. He cries a lot. My man is dead. He took his wound at Fredericksburg. Never saw his boy.

question: I'm sorry.
answer: It's pretty much what you'll get if you knock on any door of this war. Man dead, woman left. It's mean food but it's hot.

question: There's no hunting on the road, just cress and --
answer: I need to feed this man, if you could look away. Used to have a cow, few goats. Raiders took them. Made me kill our own dog on the porch. That poor creature watched over me. Nothing left now save a hog and couple of chickens to live off till spring. I'll have to kill that hog and make sense of the flesh and divisions which is something I never did.

question: I could do that for you in the morning.
answer: I'm not asking.

question: It's what I'd gladly do for you for what you're gladly doing for me. I'm Inman by the way. That's my name.
answer: I'm Sara. My baby's Ethan.

question: Glad to know you both.
answer: You look about his size. He was another man straight up and down. I don't even have a blanket.

question: I got a blanket.
answer: I'll leave you the lamp. They fit?

question: Pretty much. These boots are good boots.
answer: I'll say good night.

question: Good night.
answer: Will you come inside? Could you do something for me? Do you think you could lie here, next to me, and not need to go further?

question: I don't know. I'll try. I'll go. I'll go, shall I?
answer: I don't want you to.

question: What kind of name's Georgia?
answer: It's where he comes from, it's not his name.

question: I know that's meant to be the ugliest state under the heavens.
answer: Why do you care what his name is?

question: What's that cluster of Stars?
answer: Orion.

question: What about them shaped like a wishbone?
answer: That's Taurus the bull, and that's Gemini and that's Orion's big dog, Canis Major.

question: Listen to her, Sal. She's turned into a highland girl.
answer: I could always name the stars, Ruby, that was never my problem. I love you darling. In case that big old sky falls on our heads. And I love you, too. Sal.

question: Get out of here, quick! Federals are coming. They find you here it'll go bad on all of us.
answer: I can try and fight them.

question: No, my baby. Please no! Just get. My baby's sick! Cover him up! He's shaking! Have some pity. I got nothing. I swear. Yes! Take me inside! Let's all go inside! Take my baby inside and then we'll do whatever you want. There's nothing! You take that hog I'm as good as dead. Cover up my boy!
answer: Move away from the baby. Take off your boots. Take off your pants, and your shirt. You'd better get running before you catch your death of cold.

question: You cook something long enough you can eat anything.
answer: It's frozen. How long it been there for?

question: You hungry?
answer: Yeah.

question: Not very long. Edible.
answer: Ow!

question: Evening. Hope we didn't disturb you.
answer: You're all right.

question: Name's Teague. Do I know you?
answer: Thewes.

question: You a deserter? -- don't mind if I just warm up at your fire. That your wife?
answer: Who? That's a he!

question: He your wife?
answer: We're musicians. He picks the banjo, I got a fiddle.

question: Did you answer my question -- about your military status?
answer: Discharged. Took a wound at Petersburg.

question: Oh, so like a hero's discharge.
answer: I guess.

question: And your boyfriend?
answer: The military wouldn't take him. He can't fight. He's simple. He's got a mind no bigger'n a pickled walnut.

question: I'm sorry -- he's fat, he's simple and got titties -- but you're insisting he ain't a woman. God damn! Don't that sausage smell outstanding.
answer: Miqhty outstanding.

question: Mighty outstanding! There's a new phrase. Mighty outstanding. Listen, don't tell me -- you left your papers somewhere.
answer: Which papers?

question: Your hero's discharge. For mighty outstanding valour.
answer: They're, they're, they're at my house.

question: And where, where, where is your house?
answer: Down the mountain.

question: But you're up the mountain.
answer: Hunting. Drinking.

question: Georgia's like my armpit. Worse, it's like yours. Want some sausage?
answer: Thanks. You is Home Guard?

question: Yes, ma'am.
answer: You is Teague?

question: Stand over by that tree.
answer: Me?

question: Over by that tree. Over there. Take your boyfriend.
answer: Come on.

question: I told Georgia he can stop here, sleep in the barn. He's got nothing inside him. He'd walk out of here and die in the snow.
answer: He can milk the cows. I was worrying about that. It'll be dark in a couple of hours. I's ten hours climb from here. He's drawn a map.

question: Okay.
answer: You know these fools stayed the night in the Mill? That's Stobrod -- he can't do one good thing without adding the bad. Left tracks in the snow all the way up for them Home Guards to follow. That's a sign says shoot me!

question: Ruby, I'm so sorry.
answer: We should get going. Every piece of this is a man's bullshit. They call this a war a cloud over the land, but they made the weather. Then they stand in the rain and say

question: I don't understand.
answer: Maybe Teague's took him. They did that with the Swanger boys -- didn't, they? -- dragged them into town, then strung them up as warning... it's snowed since, so I can't read the story on the ground. Let's dig.

question: Ruby! Ruby!
answer: He's still breathing! God damn! Daddy; Daddy -- it's Ruby. Don't you die on me again. He's still breathing! Pack a pan full of snow. I need good clean water, boiled up.

question: Let's get him home. We have herbs there and it's warm.
answer: He'll die first. He's got hardly no blood left in him.

question: He'll die lying here.
answer: There's a place further on up. Used to be. Old Cherokee place. There's good water right by it.

question: This horse is weary. He's ready to give up the ghost. Good boy. That's warmer, isn't it. I'm getting firewood. That wood -- that sound when it burns that mean more snow?
answer: Yes, it do, country girl.

question: Turn round and go back where you came from.
answer: Ada? Ada Monroe?

question: I do not know you.
answer: Then I believe I made a mistake. If I knew where to go I'd go there.

question: Congratulations, I should send you out with a shotgun more often. He looks as he needs sleep.
answer: I may need to.

question: Be my guest. You shot or something?
answer: Not lately.

question: Hungry? He woke up.
answer: Stobrod?

question: Said -- your mommy's name was Grace then closed his eyes again.
answer: He's asleep. They both are.

question: I'm not surprised. Your man looks played out.
answer: I saw him. I realize now.

question: Saw him when?
answer: In Sally Swanger's well. A tunnel of trees. The man like a black smudge in the snow, the sun behind him.

question: Well there you are.
answer: Funny thing is it wasn't the same. The image. It wasn't snowing. And in the well, he was, as if he were falling.

question: You probably don't remember it right.
answer: I remember it exactly. There were crows, these black crows flying towards me. I thought I was seeing him fall. Instead I was seeing him come back to me. All this while I've been packing ice around my heart. How will I make it melt?

question: Better get a fire going. I've got big plans for that farm. Got a vision in my mind of how that Cove needs to be.
answer: I know you have.

question: I'm sorry. I was trying to be quiet.
answer: I couldn't sleep.

question: -- I got no appetite left to be in a room with wounded men.
answer: I can't see your face.

question: It's not a face you recognised.
answer: Did you get my letters?

question: I got three letters. Carried them in that book you gave me. The Bertram.
answer: I must have sent 100. Did you write to me?

question: Whenever I could. If you never got them I can summarize.
answer: No, it's --

question: I pray you're well. I pray I'm in your thoughts. You are all that keeps me from sliding into some dark place.
answer: But how did I keep you? We barely knew each other. A few moments.

question: A thousand moments. They're like a bag of tiny diamonds glittering in a black heart. Don't matter if they're real or things I made up. The shape of your neck. The way you felt under my hands when I pulled you to me.
answer: Your boots, one polished, one not yet polished.

question: You're playing a piano and I'm standing outside.
answer: I'm playing a piano and you're standing outside.

question: That kiss -- which I've kissed again every day of my walking.
answer: Every day of my waiting.

question: Now I can't see anything.
answer: I'll say goodnight.

question: I don't think Ruby's vacating my hut so that you can sleep in a different one. Come in. Whatever comes to pass between you and me, I want Ruby to stay in Black Cove.
answer: Right.

question: As long as she wants. And if she never leaves I'll be glad.
answer: More a question could she put up with me.

question: And you understand she's my friend, she's not a hired hand and she doesn't empty a night jar unless it's her own.
answer: Sure.

question: This war's made some things pointless. It's hard to imagine a wedding. I think even my father would recognize that.
answer: Ada, I want to marry you. If you'll have me.

question: Isn't there's some religion where you just have to say I marry you, three times, and then you're man and wife.
answer: I marry you. I marry you. I marry you. Why's that funny?

question: No, I think it's I divorce you three times and then you're not married anymore.
answer: I can wait for you.

question: You waited enough. I certainly did. I marry you. I marry you. I marry you. I'm sorry about the way I look. In these clothes. And there are so many buttons. Will you turn your back?
answer: Not for all the gold dollars in the Federal Bank. You go ahead. I'll follow with the horse at a pace your daddy can tolerate.

question: We can all go together.
answer: It's safer this way. No one has quarrel with you.

question: If you say a thing and then cough it's a lie. Daddy, stay on that horse, and don't lose him or sell him. We'll need him on the farm. I hope that Georgia boy's been seeing to the animals.
answer: I thought you were thinking on him!

question: I was not. I was thinking on swollen udders -- and before you say same difference...
answer: I'm saying nothing.

question: Don't look round.
answer: Got it.

question: How many men does he have?
answer: There were five. You can't reason with that man.

question: I got a conversation stopper. Closer we get to that broken ground the better. You hold on tight, do you hear? When I say three, look round, nice and slow.
answer: Okay.

question: Come out of there.
answer: No, sir. Here's fine.

question: I just have to shoot the horse from under you.
answer: Shoot her. She's not mine. You riding Mr Teague's mare?

question: I am.
answer: He dead?

question: I hope so. Look, how old are you? Give me your gun and ride home, I'm done fighting. I'm sick of it.
answer: I give you my gun you'll shoot me dead.

question: I will not shoot you, but nor am I walking down that mountain looking over my shoulder for you.
answer: That's what they call a conundrum. I tell you what I've got on my side.

question: What have you got on your side?
answer: The confidence of youth.
